title: Triggers & Sensitivities
description: Explore what triggers you during conflict and why.

questions.text: The thing that triggers me most during conflict is feeling...
choices: Dismissed or not taken seriously
Blamed or attacked
Misunderstood or not heard
Controlled or cornered

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict triggers often trace to core wounds. Dismissal-sensitive people need to matter; blame-sensitive people need safety; misunderstanding-sensitive people need to be known; control-sensitive people need autonomy. Knowing triggers prevents accidental harm.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggers require different care. Avoid your partner's triggers just as you'd want them to avoid yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared triggers create mutual understanding about what's most painful.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What triggers you most during conflict? Where did that sensitivity come from?

choices: Get louder or more intense
Withdraw or shut down
Get tearful or emotional
Become cold or distant

therapeutic.rationale: Trigger responses reveal coping patterns. Intensity-escalators fight; withdrawers flee; emotional-expressers feel; cold-distancers freeze. Recognizing your response helps you manage it and helps your partner understand.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses can escalate each other. The intensity-escalator may flood the withdrawer; the withdrawer may trigger the intensity-escalator's pursuit. Know your dance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trigger response helps you recognize when you're both activated.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you do when you're triggered? How does your partner usually respond?

questions.text: I want my partner to know that when I'm triggered...
choices: I need extra patience and gentleness
I may need space before I can talk
I'm reacting to old pain, not just this moment
I still love them even if I don't show it well

therapeutic.rationale: Trigger needs help partners respond well. Patience-needers need softness; space-needers need room; old-pain-namers need understanding; love-affirmers need reassurance. Communicating needs before triggers happen is essential.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different support. Learn what your partner needs when triggered.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trigger needs make supporting each other during activation easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need from your partner when you're triggered? Have you told them?

questions.text: Something from my past that affects how I handle conflict is...
choices: How conflict was handled in my family
Past relationships where conflict went badly
Times when I wasn't heard or respected
I try not to let the past affect me

therapeutic.rationale: Past experiences shape present conflict responses. Family patterns are deeply ingrained; past relationship wounds create fear; not-heard experiences create sensitivity; denial may hide unprocessed pain. Understanding your history helps you grow.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different histories create different sensitivities. Share your stories to understand each other's triggers.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared historical influences create mutual understanding about where patterns come from.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your past affect how you handle conflict now? What patterns do you notice?

questions.text: Knowing each other's triggers should help us...
choices: Avoid accidentally hurting each other
Be more compassionate during conflict
Understand reactions that might seem extreme
All of theseâ€”trigger awareness protects us

therapeutic.rationale: Trigger awareness serves relationship health. Avoiding hurt prevents wounds; compassion softens responses; understanding prevents judgment. Shared trigger knowledge is intimate information that requires care.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these purposes are valuable. Trigger awareness should make conflict safer, not be used as a weapon.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared understanding of trigger awareness purpose creates aligned commitment to using this knowledge well.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want trigger knowledge to be used in your relationship?
